Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is caught stealing snacks at a store, and the step-parent needs to handle the situation
Situation2: They manage high-value transactions at the end of a shift, where mistakes could cause significant financial discrepancies.
Story: I was counting the register, my mind focused on the numbers, double-checking every bill and coin. The end-of-shift tally had to be perfect—any mistake would mean hours of paperwork and a stern talk from my manager. The line was long, and I could feel the impatience of customers behind the glass. Then, out of the corner of my eye, I saw my stepson, Jamie, slipping a candy bar into his pocket. My heart dropped. I was supposed to teach him right from wrong, to be the adult he could trust and learn from. But I was also the cashier, responsible for every cent in the drawer, and the store’s policy was strict about theft. I felt the weight of both roles pressing down on me—do I call him out in front of everyone, risking his trust and our fragile relationship, or do I ignore it and risk my job and the example I set? My hands trembled as I tried to finish the transaction, my mind torn between the expectations of a step-parent and the demands of my job.
